quoteLast: . The senator from Massachusetts asks to have taken up the resolution reported by him from the Committee on Rules.

quoteFirst: Miss Radford was studying the arrival of trains list at Paddington in order to ascertain from which platform the
quoteLast: started; she had assumed the slightly demented appearance that so many take when they enter a railway station.  Turning from the poster distractedly, she clutched at the arm of a sailor, and was putting to him agitated inquiries concerning the Great Western service when Gertie Higham interposed, and released the naval man from a duty for which he was not adequately equipped.
title: Love at Paddington
author: Ridge, W. Pett (William Pett), 1859-1930

quoteFirst: Do not fear any of us; we are all devoted to this cause, and to-day shall see the end. The time is coming for action; to-day this Vampire is limit to the powers of man, and till sunset he may not change. It will take him time to arrive here--see, it is
quoteLast: --and there are yet some times before he can hither come, be he never so quick. What we must hope for is that my Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.
title: Dracula
author: Stoker, Bram, 1847-1912

quoteLast: -- less or more-- we left Columbus, and after travelling 158 miles, via Dayton, we came to Indianapolis, the great "Railroad City," as it is called, of the west. It was half past nine when we arrived there.
title: Minnesota and Dacotah
author: Andrews, C. C. (Christopher Columbus), 1829-1922

quoteFirst: We all know the kind; they use up every odd ten minutes. Robert worked from dinner, which was over about
quoteLast: , till two every day. Most men waste the hour after dinner. To Robert it meant simply two hundred hours, or about twenty-five days, at eight hours a day, every year.
title: The Master Craftsman
author: Besant, Walter, 1836-1901

quoteFirst: The summit had a thin horizontal bed of ironstone conglomerate through which masses of white sandstone protruded. This limestone country was well grassed, and thinly timbered with eucalypti of small growth; at
quoteLast: altered the course to north-east and followed down a gully in search of water; but though it gradually enlarged to a considerable creek and we continued our search till 7.0, we were compelled to encamp without water.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteLast: , Miss Carberry,” she said. “Would you like some buttermilk?”

quoteFirst: At ten minutes past midnight the red light of a Coston signal from the fort announced to the Navy that the enemy were coming.  At
quoteLast: the fight was opened by the Confederates with musketry.  Instantly the fort replied with the fire of its guns, and of every musket that could be brought to the parapet.
title: History of the Nineteenth Army Corps
author: Irwin, Richard B. (Richard Biddle), 1839-1892

Pedestrianism; or, An Account of the Performances of Celebrated Pedestrians During the Last and Present Century.

quoteFirst: Concern that the Vice President might also be a target for assassination prompted the Secret Service agents to urge him to leave the hospital and return to Washington immediately.[C2-241] The Vice President decided to wait until he received definitive word of the President’s condition.[C2-242] At approximately
quoteLast: , Vice President Johnson was notified by O’Donnell that President Kennedy was dead.[C2-243] Special Agent Youngblood learned from Mrs. Johnson the location of her two daughters and made arrangements through Secret Service headquarters in Washington to provide them with protection immediately.
title: Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteLast: 1.--Up boat, filled, and made all sail as before. Observed the _Pallas_ bear up and follow us with her convoy.

quoteFirst: Foreseeing that this manœuvre was likely to occur, Admiral Sturdee had directed the _Cornwall_, _Kent_, and _Glasgow_ to follow in pursuit. No time was lost, therefore, in giving chase to the enemy light-cruisers when they turned off to the S.S.E. at
quoteLast: , the _Glasgow_ leading the way at 26 knots, followed by the _Kent_ and the _Cornwall_ keeping neck and neck and going about 23½ knots. The _Dresden_ led the enemy light-cruisers with the _Leipzig_ and _Nürnberg_ on her starboard and port quarter respectively.
title: The Battle of the Falkland Islands, Before and After
author: Spencer-Cooper, Henry Edmund Harvey, 1884-1968

quoteFirst: She went back to her room, leaving the door ajar so that she could hear when Chris came in. He was very late--she heard the clock strike twelve, and then half-past, but still he did not come; and then--at
quoteLast: she heard a taxi drive up to the door and voices on the path outside.
title: A Bachelor Husband
author: Ayres, Ruby M. (Ruby Mildred), 1883-1955; Stahr, Paul, 1883-1953 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: "It is customary at Mawson's for the clerks to leave at midday on Saturday. Sergeant Tuson, of the City Police, was somewhat surprised therefore to see a gentleman with a carpet bag come down the steps at
quoteLast: . His suspicions being aroused, the sergeant followed the man, and with the aid of Constable Pollock succeeded, after a most desperate resistance, in arresting him. It was at once clear that a daring and gigantic robbery had been committed.
title:
The Strand Magazine, Vol. 05, Issue 27, March 1893
An Illustrated Monthly
author: Various; Newnes, George, 1851-1910 [Editor]

quoteLast: and went about eight miles; first through ‘mopani veldt,’ with fine fruit-trees in it, and a little before outspanning passed through a range of low kopjes. This ‘mopani’ is usually very heavy land, so called from the mopani trees (not unlike alders) which grow upon it. Of the fruit-trees referred to, one was my old glutinous friend of the Gwailo hunting veldt--plentiful, but not yet ripe.
title: Matabele land and the Victoria Falls
author: Oates, Frank, 1840-1875; Oates, C. G. (Charles George), 1844-1901 [Editor]
